qas.question: What was established to control the Indigenous Australians?
What did the Aboriginal Protection Boards control?

answers.text: where they lived, their employment, marriage, education and included the power to separate children from their parents.
Aborigines were not allowed to vote

qas.question: Who reported how the Aborigines were treated?
What year was his report from?

context: Being identified as either "black" or "white" in Australia during the 19th and early 20th centuries was critical in one's employment and social prospects. Various state-based <a0_0>Aboriginal Protection Boards<a0_0/> were established which had virtually complete control over the lives of Indigenous Australians – <a1_0>where they lived, their employment, marriage, education and included the power to separate children from their parents.<a1_0/> <a2_0>Aborigines were not allowed to vote<a2_0/> and were often confined to reserves and forced into low paid or effectively slave labour. The social position of mixed-race or "half-caste" individuals varied over time. A <a4_0>1913<a4_0/> report by <a3_0>Sir Baldwin Spencer<a3_0/> states that:
